prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IIZw96 Band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This proposal aims to obtain the continuum energy spectral distribution (SED) and the CO line SED (SLED) given by Bands 3, 6 and 7, for at least three different locations within the merging galaxy IIZw96. The chosen bands are ideal to observe the transition from a regime where non-thermal, thermal and dust emission contributes to the SED (<90 GHz) to that where the SED is dominated only by the thermal dust emission (>100 GHz). These ALMA observations are crucial for our purpose since they will complement ancillary JVLA and Herschel/SPIRE observations of this system. With these ALMA observations we will be able to understand and characterize the different environments present in this merger-driven starburst galaxy and probe the different physics mechanisms at play. By knowing the details of these local systems, we will be able to better understand the integrated parameters of high redshifts analogs.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target continuum emission from bands 3, 6 and 7. As a secondary goal we aim to obtain the molecular gas tracers CO (1-0), CO(2-1) and CO (3-2) transitions at the respective bands.
SPECTRAL SETUP: The correlator setup is such that 3 out of the 4 available basebands are destined to continuum observations with the maximum bandwidth, and the fourth one is commissioned to CO observation with 1.875 GHz bandwidth.The peak flux for the CO transition lines are calculated from other LIRG studies (e.g., Leech et al. 2010) and assuming tipical ratios for starburst galaxies.
RESOLUTION: We aim for 1" spatial scales in order to obtain enough resolution to resolve and detect extended emission from the components of IIZw96 in a reasonable amount of time. Supporting this choice, Figure 1 (right panel) shows that we will be able to place many resolution elements throughout the galaxy and recover extended structures.
ANGULAR SCALE: For the largest angular scale used in the calculations, we assume 6" which correspond to the angular scale of the off nuclear starburst extended emission seen at the JVLA C band image (see figure 1). The use of ACA is not necessary for our observations.\\
SENSITIVITY: The sensitivity requirements are all driven by the expected continuum flux, at 1" resolution, for the nucleus of the spiral component of IIZw96 (component C in Figure 1), which correspond to the faintest of the three targeted components. In all the cases the required sensitivity is such that we expect a 7$\sigma$ detection at the center of the spiral galaxy. To calculate the required sensitivity at band 3, we use the available JVLA 33 GHz data for this galaxy (Barcos-Mu\~noz et al. in prep), smoothed to 1" resolution. We assume a normal thermal spectral index (-0.1) in order to predict the expected peak flux of the nucleus of the spiral galaxy at 90 GHz. Since the assumed spectral index is shallow this approximation is reasonable throughout band 3. The required final sensitivity for this band is 15 $\mu$Jy/beam, which will give us a 7$\sigma$ detection for the nucleus of the spiral galaxy. The estimated required on source time is 41.6 minutes per pointing. With this amount of time we are able to detect a CO (1-0) surface brightness rms of 4 $\mathrm{M_{\odot}/pc^{2}}$, calculated assuming a bandwidth per polarization of 50 km/s. An active normal spiral has a CO surface brightness in the range of 10-50 $\mathrm{M_{\odot}/pc^{2}}$, which means we will be able to detect the CO(1-0) emission in the spiral galaxy and thus on the other two components of IIZw96. The ALMA field of view available at band 3 is larger enough to fit the entire galaxy within it, so we require only one pointing at this band. The total time required at band 3, including calibrations and overheads is 1.32 hours. We perform our calculations using a representative frequency corresponding to a continuum commissioned baseband, such that the atmospheric conditions are the best among the chosen continuum basebands.
DATA RATE: The data rate produced in this proposal is within the limits and nothing of concern.
SPECIAL CONSTRAINTS: For all the observations the overheads account for more than the 30\% of the total time and they exceed the 40 min on source time (lengthy observations), this is determine by the high sensitivity required in order to accomplish our goal of detecting a faint component in IIZw96.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IIZw96 Band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This proposal aims to obtain the continuum energy spectral distribution (SED) and the CO line SED (SLED) given by Bands 3, 6 and 7, for at least three different locations within the merging galaxy IIZw96. The chosen bands are ideal to observe the transition from a regime where non-thermal, thermal and dust emission contributes to the SED (<90 GHz) to that where the SED is dominated only by the thermal dust emission (>100 GHz). These ALMA observations are crucial for our purpose since they will complement ancillary JVLA and Herschel/SPIRE observations of this system. With these ALMA observations we will be able to understand and characterize the different environments present in this merger-driven starburst galaxy and probe the different physics mechanisms at play. By knowing the details of these local systems, we will be able to better understand the integrated parameters of high redshifts analogs.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target continuum emission from bands 3, 6 and 7. As a secondary goal we aim to obtain the molecular gas tracers CO (1-0), CO(2-1) and CO (3-2) transitions at the respective bands.
SPECTRAL SETUP: The correlator setup is such that 3 out of the 4 available basebands are destined to continuum observations with the maximum bandwidth, and the fourth one is commissioned to CO observation with 1.875 GHz bandwidth.The peak flux for the CO transition lines are calculated from other LIRG studies (e.g., Leech et al. 2010) and assuming tipical ratios for starburst galaxies.
RESOLUTION: We aim for 1" spatial scales in order to obtain enough resolution to resolve and detect extended emission from the components of IIZw96 in a reasonable amount of time. Supporting this choice, Figure 1 (right panel) shows that we will be able to place many resolution elements throughout the galaxy and recover extended structures.
ANGULAR SCALE: For the largest angular scale used in the calculations, we assume 6" which correspond to the angular scale of the off nuclear starburst extended emission seen at the JVLA C band image (see figure 1). The use of ACA is not necessary for our observations.\\
SENSITIVITY: The sensitivity requirements are all driven by the expected continuum flux, at 1" resolution, for the nucleus of the spiral component of IIZw96 (component C in Figure 1), which correspond to the faintest of the three targeted components. In all the cases the required sensitivity is such that we expect a 7$\sigma$ detection at the center of the spiral galaxy. To calculate the sensitivity at band 6 required to observe the nucleus of the spiral galaxy at a 7$\sigma$ level, we use the M82 SED from Condon (1992) from which we calculate the ratio between the thermal dust continuum at band 6 and the JVLA 6 GHz continuum flux for this feature. We require a sensitivity of 20 $\mu$Jy/beam, which implies an on source time of 45.29 minutes per pointing. With this amount of time we are able to detect a CO (2-1) surface brightness rms of 0.3 $\mathrm{M_{\odot}/pc^{2}}$, calculated assuming a bandwidth per polarization of 50 km/s. Even though the sensitivity improves at this band, the CO (2-1) transition is fainter than the CO (1-0). Typical values for CO (2-1) surface brightnesses for an active normal spiral go from 5-10 $\mathrm{M_{\odot}/pc^{2}}$, which promise success in the detection of CO(2-1) throughout the galaxy. The ALMA field of view available at band 6 fits the entire galaxy within it. We might expect some sensitivity loss toward the edges of the galaxy, however they do not concern us since the nucleus of the spiral is within 1/3 of the field of view, so we require only one pointing at this band. The total time required at band 6, including calibrations and overheads is 1.43 hours. We perform our calculations using a representative frequency corresponding to a continuum commissioned baseband, such that the atmospheric conditions are the best among the chosen continuum basebands.
DATA RATE: The data rate produced in this proposal is within the limits and nothing of concern.
SPECIAL CONSTRAINTS: For all the observations the overheads account for more than the 30\% of the total time and they exceed the 40 min on source time (lengthy observations), this is determine by the high sensitivity required in order to accomplish our goal of detecting a faint component in IIZw96.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IIZw96 Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This proposal aims to obtain the continuum energy spectral distribution (SED) and the CO line SED (SLED) given by Bands 3, 6 and 7, for at least three different locations within the merging galaxy IIZw96. The chosen bands are ideal to observe the transition from a regime where non-thermal, thermal and dust emission contributes to the SED (<90 GHz) to that where the SED is dominated only by the thermal dust emission (>100 GHz). These ALMA observations are crucial for our purpose since they will complement ancillary JVLA and Herschel/SPIRE observations of this system. With these ALMA observations we will be able to understand and characterize the different environments present in this merger-driven starburst galaxy and probe the different physics mechanisms at play. By knowing the details of these local systems, we will be able to better understand the integrated parameters of high redshifts analogs.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target continuum emission from bands 3, 6 and 7. As a secondary goal we aim to obtain the molecular gas tracers CO (1-0), CO(2-1) and CO (3-2) transitions at the respective bands.
SPECTRAL SETUP: The correlator setup is such that 3 out of the 4 available basebands are destined to continuum observations with the maximum bandwidth, and the fourth one is commissioned to CO observation with 1.875 GHz bandwidth.The peak flux for the CO transition lines are calculated from other LIRG studies (e.g., Leech et al. 2010) and assuming tipical ratios for starburst galaxies.
RESOLUTION: We aim for 1" spatial scales in order to obtain enough resolution to resolve and detect extended emission from the components of IIZw96 in a reasonable amount of time. Supporting this choice, Figure 1 (right panel) shows that we will be able to place many resolution elements throughout the galaxy and recover extended structures.
ANGULAR SCALE: For the largest angular scale used in the calculations, we assume 6" which correspond to the angular scale of the off nuclear starburst extended emission seen at the JVLA C band image (see figure 1). The use of ACA is not necessary for our observations.\\
SENSITIVITY: The sensitivity requirements are all driven by the expected continuum flux, at 1" resolution, for the nucleus of the spiral component of IIZw96 (component C in Figure 1), which correspond to the faintest of the three targeted components. In all the cases the required sensitivity is such that we expect a 7$\sigma$ detection at the center of the spiral galaxy. To calculate the sensitivity at band 7 required to observe the nucleus of the spiral galaxy at a 7$\sigma$ level, we use the M82 SED from Condon (1992) from which we calculate the ratio between the thermal dust continuum at band 7 and the JVLA 6 GHz continuum flux for this feature. We require a sensitivity of 32.2 $\mu$Jy/beam, which implies an on source time of 45.36 minutes per pointing. With this amount of time we are able to detect a CO (3-2) surface brightness rms of 0.2 $\mathrm{M_{\odot}/pc^{2}}$, calculated assuming a bandwidth per polarization of 50 km/s. The CO (3-2) transition is also fainter than the CO (2-1). A typical CO (3-2) surface brightness value for an active normal spiral is 1-5 $\mathrm{M_{\odot}/pc^{2}}$, which promise success in the detection of CO(2-1) throughout the galaxy. The ALMA field of view available at band 7 is not big enough to fit the entire galaxy, so two pointings are necessary to obtain the entire galaxy. The total time required at band 7, including calibrations and overheads is 3.15 hours. We perform our calculations using a representative frequency corresponding to a continuum commissioned baseband, such that the atmospheric conditions are the best among the chosen continuum basebands.
DATA RATE: The data rate produced in this proposal is within the limits and nothing of concern.
SPECIAL CONSTRAINTS: For all the observations the overheads account for more than the 30\% of the total time and they exceed the 40 min on source time (lengthy observations), this is determine by the high sensitivity required in order to accomplish our goal of detecting a faint component in IIZw96.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe millimeter to submillimeter continuum emission from the resolved major merger and borderline ultra luminous infrared galaxy IIZw96 at a 1" spatial resolution using bands 3, 6 and 7. These observations will allow us constrain the variation of the SED as a function of location within the system. We also plan to simultaneously observe the CO (1-0), (2-1) and (3-2) transitions available in order to obtain a CO SLED as a function of position. This is part of a larger effort (together with the JVLA) to build a full resolved SED for IIZw96. ALMA is the only telescope that can fill in the submillimeter regime with the suitable sensitivity and resolution for this purpose. These resolved continuum and CO lines SEDs will allow us to determine: 1) the relative strengths of the SED components (free-free, synchrotron and dust emission) and how they vary across the interacting system, 2) the true distribution of the free-free continuum emission, and 3) the fraction of the total continuum emission that comes from diffuse extended emission. This information will serve as a starting point to interpret SED and CO SLED of high-redshift unresolved major mergers.
